awd_titl_txt: New Hybrid Materials by Controlled Polymerization of Monomers with Bulky Functional Substituents
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This research project is focused on synthesis, characterization and potential applications of well-defined polymers containing bulky functional substituents (BFS). Until recently many polymers with precisely controlled architectures were prepared, yet essentially with small chemical substituents attached onto their molecules. The main aim of this project is to enlarge the range of these substituents to include various BFS such as inorganics, biomolecules or short polymer chains in the form of macromonomers. The resulting polymers will have a very high local concentration of functional groups and consequently could provide new materials with unusual thermal, mechanical, optoelectronic or biological properties. Unfortunately, direct polymerization of monomers with BFS is very challenging and therefore this research will explore new pathways to overcome these challenges. This project should impact not only science, but also education and our society. Undergraduate and graduate students, a postdoctoral fellow, and visitors from collaborative groups will work together in the PI's group and with industrial members of a consortium on specialized novel polymerization techniques. Some hybrid functional materials resulting from the proposed activities may be of commercial importance and should benefit our society. Dissemination of information will be accomplished by publications, presentations at national and international meetings and at the PI's web site. 



TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This main aim of this research is synthesis, characterization and potential applications of polymers with bulky functional substituents (BFS) such as inorganic nanoparticles, short polymer chains, or biomolecules. BFS reduce thermodynamic and kinetic polymerizability of such monomers, and new pathways and reaction conditions to overcome these challenges will be explored. Three classes of monomers with BSF will be investigated: (i) inorganic systems with polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxanes (POSS) with various substituents as well as gold nanoclusters with spacers linking them to polymerizable (meth)acrylate group; (ii) macromonomers based on poly(ethylene oxide) and poly(n-butyl acrylate) with (meth)acrylate function; (iii) biomolecules (proteins or oligonucleotides) linked to (meth)acrylamide polymerizable groups. They will be polymerized under the range of conditions (solvent, concentrations, pressure, chemical or physical activators, pre-assembly) to generate novel hybrid materials with high local concentration of bulky functional groups. Their properties (thermomechanical, catalytic, bio-relevant) will be thoroughly characterized and their potential applications will be explored. The generated information will be disseminated through the PI's website, timely publications, student presentations at national and international conferences, and also to industry through the industrial consortium at Carnegie Mellon. Some hybrid functional materials resulting from the proposed activities may be of commercial importance and should benefit our society.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the project were to polymerize monomers with bulky functional substituents by Atom Transfer Radical Polymerization (ATRP) and to characterize properties of the resulting polymers. ATRP is an important method for synthesis of well-defined polymers and is already commercially used by several companies world-wide. Therefore, it is important to expand range of monomers and include those with inorganic side groups and also biomolecules. The lower, polymerizability of monomers with bulky substituents offered a potential depolymerization of the prepared polymers back to monomers. The intellectual merit included development of conditions for efficient polymerization of monomers with bulky substituents and also depolymerization of the resulting polymethacrylates. Various biomolecules such proteins, nucleic acids and even biological vesicles such as exosomes were polymerized and incorporated into branched complex architecture. The project encompassed computational modeling, kinetic and mechanistic studies, and polymer synthesis and characterization. Polymerizations were carried out in organic media but also in water under homogeneous and heterogeneous conditions. Some polymerizations were carried out in open to air atmosphere.  The research carried out had a broader impact on other disciplines. The polymers with complex architecture, including organic-inorganic hybrids and bioconjugates form interesting commercially important materials with applications ranging from reinforced plastics, targeted delivery systems, electrocatalysis and for. environmentally benign materials The project involved education of graduate, undergraduate students and postdoctoral fellows. They were exposed to the most recent and advanced synthetic techniques in radical polymerization processes and characterization of polymeric materials. They regularly presented at semiannual Consortium meetings and also at national and international symposia. Their research was recognized by several awards at CMU (Stefanie Kwolek Fellowship for Yuan 2018, Wang 2019 and Cuthbert 2020; Harrison Fellowship for Ribelli 2017, Dadashi Silab 2019 and Martinez 2021); international recognition such as Chateaubriand Fellowship for Ribelli 2018 and Sobieski 2021; as well as Chinese Government Award for Outstanding Self-Financed Students Abroad (He 2015 and Li 2020). They started successful careers in either academia or industry. During the project, PI was recognized by four honorary degrees (Haifa 2015, Poznan 2016, Padova 2017 and Coimbra 2018), he received Dreyfus Prize in Chemical Sciences (2015), Benjamin Franklin Medal in Chemistry (2017), William Nichols Medal (ACS NY Section 2020), Grand Prix de la Fondation de la Chemie (France 2021) and was selected by CNRS as Ambassador of Chemical Sciences in France in 2022.. He also received ACS Award in Chemistry of Materials and Paul Flory Polymer Education Award (2020). He was elected to National Academy of Sciences (2019), to Australian (2019) and European Academy of Sciences (2020).  The main dissemination process was through timely publications: 140 papers were published in peer-review journals and books. Our web site was visited over 50,000 times annually and it provides introductory and advanced information on controlled radical polymerization systems. In 2017, the ACS Symposium on Controlled Radical Polymerization (CRP) was organized with ca. 100 oral and 100 poster presentations, in addition to ACS workshop on CRP in Charleston 2021.  Controlled radical polymerization is of significant commercial interest as evidenced by 60 international companies that have participated it the industrial consortium at Carnegie Mellon and 17 signed licenses resulting in new products commercialized in US, Europe and Japan. During Covid19 lab shut down, Matyjaszewski group members organized a series of webinars with over 3000 participants from the entire world, inviting 11 senior polymer chemists and 11 postdocs and graduate students to present cutting edge polymer science.

 


Last Modified: 07/28/2022
Modified by: Krzysztof Matyjaszewski
